metadata.title: Pandas made easy (the guide). With many examples of some of the most… | by Gonçalo Guimarães Gomes | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Being one of the most preferred and used tools that every Data Scientist knows very well and works with, the Pandas library is awesome for data manipulation, analysis, and visualization and should be…

all_paragraphs: Being one of the most preferred and used tools that every Data Scientist knows very well and works with, the Pandas library is awesome for data manipulation, analysis, and visualization and should be also flowing under your fingers any time soon, if you practice a lot.

To help you to accomplish that mission and being more confident with your Python coding, I have created this guide with some of the most used functions and methods on Pandas. I truly hope this may be useful to you.
0. Import library1. Import/export data2. Display Data3. Basic Info: a quick look at the data4. Basic Statistics5. Tweaking Data6. Boolean indexing: loc7. Boolean indexing: iloc8. Basic Handling Data

We will be working on the ‘Titanic’ data set for two main reasons: (1) most probably you are somehow already familiarized with it and (2) it’s very small, simple, and has (and has not) all the data we need for illustrating with examples.
The Titanic data set is available for download here.
For our purpose, ‘pandas’ library is our weapon to get started.
The ‘Titanic data set’ is assigned as ‘data’ along with the article.
a) Import a csv file into the notebook using read_csv. You should add the type of separation of the data in the file.
b) Read the data from an excel file using read_excel.
c) Export the data frame to a csv file using to_csv, comma separated and without index. If None is given, header and index are True.
d) Export the data frame to a excel file using to_excel.
a) Printing the first ’n’ rows. If None is given, display 5 rows by default.
b) Printing the last ’n’ rows. Below, displaying the 7 last rows.
a) Displaying the dimension of the data set: the total number of rows, columns.
b) Displaying the type of variables.
c) Displaying the type of variables by ordered values.
e) Counting values of each type, by ordered values.
f) Checking balance between the number of survivers vs non-survivers, in absolute values.
g) Checking the features' proportion, in percentage.
h) Checking the features' proportion, in percentage, rounded by 4.
i) Evaluating the presence of missing values in the data set.
j) Number of missing values by variable using isnull().
k) Number of existing values using notnull().
l) Percentage (%) of missing values by variable.
m) Rounding the decimal values (by 2, in the example).
n) Bonus: printing the answers using combined text.
o) General overview of shape, variables’ type and missing values.
p) General overview of specific features (‘Sex’ and ‘Age’ in the example below).
a) The describe method gives us only basic statistics about the data. By default, it will only calculate the main stats for numeric data. The result is represented as a pandas data frame.
b) Adding other non-standard values, for instance, the ‘variance’.
… is also the same as:
d) By passing the parameter include='all', will display both numeric and non-numeric data at once.
e) Do not forget to transpose the data frame by adding the .T at the end. This is also a very useful resource applicable in every data frame.
f) Calculus of percentiles 1%, 5%, 95%, 99%. As expected, it will only calculate stats for numerical features.
Q1 — Showing the 2 most frequent unique of the categorical feature ‘Embarked’.
Q2 — What is the percentage of ‘Embarked’ highest unique? (fraction of the most common unique in regards to all the others).
i) Correlations between variables. As expected, it will only display stats for numeric data.
data.corr() # Pearson’s correlation by default
J) Correlation between a chosen variable (‘Survived’ in the example) and the others.
b) Rename some column (‘PassengerId’ by ‘id’ in the example below).
d) Replacing underscores by dots through a list comprehension (applyed to ‘Passenger_Id’, ‘P_Class’ and ‘ Sib_Sp’ only).
e) Lowering upper characters and removing the dots (applyed to ‘Passenger.Id’, ‘P.Class’ and ‘ Sib.Sp’ only).
data.columns = [x.capitalize() for x in data.columns]
data.loc[<lines>, <columns>] # select by position and names
b) Selecting an array of rows.
d) Selecting a row from several columns ‘Name, ‘Age’, ‘Sex’ and ‘Survived’.
e) Selecting many rows from several columns.
f) Selecting specific values under some condition using loc. In this case, from rows 4 to 10 select passengers older or equal to 10 years old.
g) Selecting specific values under some condition using loc. In this case, from the first 5 rows select passengers who traveled in Cabin C123.
data.iloc[<lines>, <columns>] # Select by position and numbers
a) Selecting the first row of the data set.
b) Selecting an array of rows from all the columns.
c) Selecting several rows from all the columns.
d) Selecting a row from the columns ‘Name, ‘Age’, ‘Sex’ and ‘Survived’.
e) Selecting many rows from several columns.
f) Selecting many rows form a sequence of columns.
data.isnull().values.any()# Are there any missing data?
If not assigning it into a (new) variable, you should specify inplace=True so that any changes can take effect on the same assessment.
data.dropna(axis=0, inplace=True)# Removing nan from rows
data.isnull().values.any()# Are there any missing data?
c) Value counts can also display NaN values.
The mean (average) value of data.Age:
I sincerely hope you find this guide useful as it can contribute to your development writing code. I will be updating it in the future and link it to other Python tutorials.
Please post in the comments below other functions and methods you can’t live without and should be highlighted. I would like to hear from you!
